title: 110_s1556
content: The Act is titled the "Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act" and it applies accident and health plans to eligible beneficiaries. The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries and qualifying children under accident and health plans. It also excludes amounts expended for medical care. The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and dependents under accident and health plans. It also excludes amounts expended for medical care. The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and dependents under accident and health plans. It also excludes amounts expended for medical care, including eligible beneficiaries with respect to employees and their qualifying children. The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act expands coverage under accident and health plans to include eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and dependents. It also clarifies the definition of eligible beneficiaries and their qualifying children. The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act expands coverage under accident and health plans to include eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and dependents. It clarifies the definition of eligible beneficiaries and their qualifying children within the meaning of section 106(f). The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act amends section 3401(a) of the Code to include eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and dependents in accident and health plan coverage. It clarifies the definition of eligible beneficiaries and their qualifying children under section 106(f). The Tax Equity for Domestic Partner and Health Plan Beneficiaries Act clarifies the definition of eligible beneficiaries and their qualifying children under section 106(f). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. Expansion of dependency for deduction of health insurance costs for self-employed individuals. Expansion of dependency for deduction of health insurance costs for self-employed individuals. Amendment to section 162(l) of the Internal Revenue Code allows a deduction for insurance payments made by self-employed taxpayers for medical care for themselves, their spouse, dependents, and certain individuals who meet specific criteria. The text discusses the criteria for individuals who can be designated by a taxpayer for the purpose of claiming a deduction for insurance payments under section 162(l) of the Internal Revenue Code. The designated individual must meet specific requirements outlined in section 152(d)(1)(C) and (D), and cannot be the taxpayer's spouse or have certain relationships with the taxpayer as defined in section 152(d)(2). Only one person can be designated for this purpose. The amendment allows for an individual described in paragraph (1)(E) to be designated by the taxpayer for claiming a deduction for insurance payments under section 162(l) of the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4. Extension to eligible beneficiaries of sick and accident benefits provided to members of a voluntary employees' beneficiary association and their dependents. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 5. Flexible spending arrangements and health reimbursement arrangements. The Secretary of Treasury will issue guidance allowing medical expenses eligible for reimbursement from flexible spending arrangements and health reimbursement arrangements to be reimbursed, regardless of the beneficiary or qualifying child. The Secretary of Treasury will issue guidance allowing medical expenses eligible for reimbursement from health reimbursement arrangements to be reimbursed for individuals designated by the employee. SEC. 6 extends qualified medical expenses from health savings accounts to include any qualified beneficiary, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
